Toxics - NONE


Flammables

Propylene: Approximately 1,500,000 lbs. are stored and used on-site.  Propylene is refined in the Olefins.

Olefins Condensate: Approximately 129 million lbs. of mixed condensate feedstocks, intermediates, and products are present within the Olefins process units and in the tank farm area.  The condensates include Algerian, OP-400, and Naptha condensate materials, depending in most part to the supplier.  


Isobutylene: Approximately 1.1 million lbs. are contained in storage and within the East Plant process unit.  Isobutylene is an intermediate chemical used in the production of MTBE.

1,3-Butadiene: Approximately 3.5 million pounds of Butadiene are stored and in process within the East Plant.  Butadiene is further utilized on the Poly-Butadiene process within the Mid Plant as well as sold as a finished product.

N-Butane: Approximately 1.3 million lbs. are contained in storage and within the East Plant process unit.  N-Butane is an intermediate chemical and is sent to the Olefins Cracking Units for further processing.

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.

Compliance Audits: CVON conducts audits on a regular basis to verify the provisions set forth under the PSM and RMP rules are being implemented.  These audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years.

Employee Participation: CVON plant has a program to ensure that maintenance and operations personnel are involved in all prevention program elements.  Each operating area also has a representative on the Plant Safety Committee.

Contractor Safety Program: The plant has a program to ensure that contractors are properly trained, and uses the Houston Area Contractors Association as a tool to provide the basic HSE training required of a contractor prior to entering a chemical manufacturing facility.  All contractor employees must attend the Houston Area Contractors Association training and be certified through examination prior to arriving at the plant.  In addition to basic training CVON site specific training is required prior to arriving at the plant.


Five Year Accident History

None.
 

Emergency Response

CVON maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  This program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, CVON coordinates with the community response plan through the North Channel and Highlands LEPC, as well as the Harris County Office of Emergency Management.  CVON is also a participating member of the Houston area Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary ¿  December 20, 2006


1.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

At the EQUISTAR ¿ Channelview Plant (CVON) we are committed to operating and maintaining our processes to protect our employees, the public, and the environment.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure continued operations with protection in environmental, health and safety (EHS) protection in mind.  This document provides a  brief overview of our comprehensive risk management activities to prevent or eliminate the possibility of an accidental release of a regulated chemical.

It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent the release of a regulated substance, however, if such a release does occur, our trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of any release.   We are also coordinated with the Houston area¿s Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) which provides additional emergency response expertise.

Chlorine was removed from the cooling towers effective 12/18/2006, and replaced with a 10% bleach solution for the prevention and control of biological organism growth.  We still utilize an internal standard of 0.5 ¿ 1.0 ppm free chloride in our cooling towers as found in the bleach solution.  The removal of Chlorine from our cooling towers prompted this change in our RMP submission.

General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

EQUISTAR Chemicals ¿ Channelview Operations (CVON) has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68.  Addiitonally, this facility was designed and constructed in accordance with strict internal engineering standards as well as is subject to the requirements under 29 CFR 1910.119 ¿ Process Safety Management.

Process Safety Information: Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, kept up-to-date, and made available to operating personnel.

Process Hazards Analyses (PHAs): A rigorous practice of reviewing new processes or changes to existing processes at the design stage, with the overall thougth of identifying and mitigating HSE issues before installation or operation.  Scheduled PHAs are conducted every 5 years to revalidate previous hazard reviews and recommend corrective actions to prevent accidents.

Operating Procedures: Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are kept up-to-date constantly thru a review during any SOP training opportunity.  Operating procedures are based on process hazard / risk reviews and are periodically modified after completed of a process PHA.  Operating procedures include safe start-up and emergency shutdown of a pro

cess unit.

Operator Training / Certification Program: CVON has a training and testing program that ensures that operators have the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.  Periodic operator re-certification is required.

Computerized Process Simulation: Computerized simulation programs are used for training and troubleshooting and include emergency shutdown and start-up simulations.

Maintenance Procedures: CVON has specific procedures for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely.  Plant and unit specific procedures for servicing operating equipment are in place, including a preventive / predictive maintenance and reliability programs.

Maintenance Training: CVON trains and test mechanics and other craftsmen who perform routine or complex maintenance tasks on process equipment and inspections on operating equipment to ensure they have the required knowledge and skills.

Mechanical Integrity Program: Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment, are periodically tested and inspected to ensure safe operations, following recognized standards and governmental requirements.  

Quality Assurance: CVON has a system to ensure that purchased equipment and materials meet established engineering standards and specifications.

Process Change Authorizations (Management of Change / PCAs): CVON has a management system to ensure that modifications to a process or  facilities are evaluated to ensure continued safe operations.  Design (DSRs) and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) are conducted for facility or process changes prior to implementation of the change.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs): Reviews conducted just prior to startup to ensure that modified facilities or processes are safe to operate.
